title-group.article-title: Clean wet-filament winding – Part 1: design concept and simulations

article-meta.aff: 1Sensors and Composites Group, School of Metallurgy and Materials, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, UK

author-notes.corresp: GF Fernando, Sensors and Composites Group, School of Metallurgy and Materials, University of Birmingham, Edgbaston, Birmingham, B15 2TT, UK. Email: g.fernando@bham.ac.uk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This is a two-part paper where part 1 presents details of a modified wet-filament winding process. Here, the resin bath was replaced with a resin injection system that impregnated the fibres prior to winding them onto a rotating mandrel. The resin and hardener were stored in separate containers and pumped on-demand via a pair of precision gear-pumps to a static mixer. The mixed resin system was then supplied to a custom-designed resin impregnation unit. The theoretical basis for the design of the resin impregnation unit is presented along with simulations of the various parameters that influence the impregnation time and the degree of impregnation. Part 2 of this series papers presents the experimental data on the performance of the resin impregnation unit and a comparison of the physical and mechanical properties of the tubes manufactured using the conventional and modified wet-filament winding techniques.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Conventional filament winding is an established manufacturing technique that is used to produce fibre-reinforced composite components such as pipes, printer rollers and pressure vessels. There are a number of variations associated with this manufacturing technique including the following: (i) resin bath-based impregnation;1 (ii) dry-tape winding;2–4 (iii) electrostatic deposition;5,6 and (iv) laser-assisted impregnation.2,7,8 The resin bath-based impregnation method is the predominant technique used in industry and generally involves the use of thermosetting resin systems. The term ‘resin system’ is used here to describe an intimately mixed resin and hardener.

A schematic illustration of the conventional wet-filament winding method is shown in Figure 1. The reinforcing fibre bundles from the creels or bobbins (A) are fed through a series of guides (B) and a tensioning system (C); a further set of guide pins (D) control the trajectory of the fibres onto a drum impregnator (E) located in a resin bath (F). The individual components of the resin system (for example, epoxy and amine) are mixed manually in the required stoichiometric proportions before being poured into the resin bath. The impregnated fibres (G) are directed to a traversing carriage (H) and a ‘D-eye’ (I) which gathers the impregnated fibre bundles into a ribbon prior to winding them onto a rotating mandrel (J). The carriage traverses horizontally along the length of the rotating mandrel, laying resin-impregnated fibres in a pre-determined fashion onto the mandrel. The desired winding angle of the fibres is achieved by controlling the traverse rate of the carriage and rotation speed of the mandrel. Figure 1.
Schematic illustration of the conventional wet-filament winding process. The key components are coded as follows: (A) fibre creels; (B) fibre guide; (C) tensioning systems; (D) guide pins; (E) drum-impregnator with a doctor-blade; (F) resin bath; (G) impregnated fibre bundles; (H) traversing carriage; (I) D-eye; and (J) rotating mandrel.

With reference to Figure 1, the following section discusses some of the problems associated with conventional wet-filament winding:
Pot-life of the pre-mixed resin system: In general, thermosetting resin systems used in wet-filament winding have a finite ‘pot-life’. The term pot-life refers to the period where the mixed resin and hardener (and catalyst) remain usable. After this period, the progressive cross-linking of the resin results in a concomitant increase in the viscosity; therefore, the wetting of the fibres and the impregnation process becomes progressively more difficult as the viscosity of the resin system increases.
The resin bath: The limited pot-life also means that the resin system can ‘set’ or cross-link into a solid in the resin bath; the consequence of this will be serious as it will require the cross-linked resin to be removed prior to the resumption of production. The limited pot-life also means that fast-curing resin systems are not generally suitable for conventional wet-filament winding.
Solvents: A major issue with conventional wet-filament winding with thermosetting resin systems is the need for the equipment to be cleaned thoroughly at the end of each production run. In general, depending on the dimensions of the resin bath, the cleaning operation can consume litres of solvent. Legislation or local protocols dictate the need for the solvent to be recovered prior to disposal of the sludge. Obviously, all these issues can contribute to the overall cost of production.
Manual mixing and pouring: In conventional wet-filament winding, the resin and hardener are weighed-out in the required stoichiometric ratio and mixed manually. Degassing of the mixed resin system is not generally performed. The mixed resin system is then poured into the resin bath. During the filament winding operation, the resin bath has to be replenished manually with the mixed resin system. The consumables required include disposable containers and stirrers, and absorbent paper to clean any resin drips. These items also have to be disposed.
Excess resin: Irrespective of the mode of impregnation of the fibre tows, immersion-based or drum-based, the excess resin system remaining in the resin bath at the end of production is transferred to a disposable container; this resin system is allowed to cross-link to a solid prior to disposal. Since the cross-linking reactions in thermosetting resins are exothermic, precautions have to be taken to avoid the resin system from exotherming. In other words, the heat liberated during cross-linking can lead to auto-acceleration of the reactions. This can lead to the thermo-oxidative degradation of the resin system. Therefore, with large resin baths, the waste resin system has to be split into smaller volumes prior to curing to minimise the likelihood of an exotherm. In situations where the reinforcing fibres are over-impregnated, the excess resin on the fibres on the mandrel is removed manually; this also contributes to the overall volume of the waste resin during production.
Aeration: In the case of drum-based impregnation, the rotation of the drum can lead to aeration of the resin system. This in turn can potentially lead to poor impregnation of the fibres and increase the void content.

With reference to the above-mentioned issues, the current paper presents the design, development and demonstration of a ‘Clean’ wet-filament winding technique. In summary, in the Clean wet-filament winding process, the resin bath is replaced with a resin impregnation unit that impregnates the reinforcing fibres. Manual mixing of the resin and hardener is avoided by using a conventional resin dispensing unit in conjunction with a static mixer. The design basis for the resin impregnation unit is also presented.

sec.title: Clean filament winding: design concept
sec.p:
A schematic illustration of the key components of the Clean wet-filament winding process is presented in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Schematic illustration of the clean filament winding concept. The key components are coded as follows: (i) resin dispensing unit; (ii) resin reservoir; (iii) hardener reservoir; (iv and v) precision gear pumps; (vi) manifold; (vii) static mixer; (viii) resin impregnation unit located on the traverse carriage; (ix) rotating mandrel; (x) tensioning and fibre spreading stations; (xi) creels or bobbins; and (xii) feedback control system to enable synchronisation between the mandrel and the resin dispensing unit.

The following section presents a description of the components cited in Figure 2.
Resin/hardener containment and delivery system: Here the resin and hardener are contained in separate reservoirs and pumped on-demand via precision gear-pumps into a custom-made manifold. In this manifold, the two liquid streams are directed into a conventional Kenics™ static mixer. The precision pumps used in this study were capable of delivering 10–110 g.min−1 of resin and hardener and capable of handling liquids with viscosities of 20–10,000 mPa.s. The resin dispensing unit was manufactured by CTM, UK. A canister of silica gel (desiccant) is secured on the lids of the resin and hardener reservoirs to minimize the absorption of atmospheric moisture. The resin containment and delivery system described here negates the need for manual mixing of the resin and hardener components.
Manifold: The independent liquid streams (resin and hardener) from the precision pumps are directed to a manifold (50 mm width, 42.5 mm height and 25 mm thickness) that is connected to the static mixer.
Mixing the resin and hardener: In the clean filament winding process, the resin and hardener are ‘mixed’ intimately via a static mixer. The static mixer consists of a series of helical elements, which are fixed within a tubular housing. The consecutive elements oppose each other and are welded together such that the adjacent edges are perpendicular. As a consequence of this, the fluid is split every time it leaves one element and enters another. This process continues along the length of the static mixer. The striation thickness is reduced by a factor 2 N where N = the number of splitting elements. With the appropriate selection of the number of helical elements in the static mixer, a good homogenisation of the resin system can be attained.9 The deployment of the static mixer negates the need to mix the resin and hardener manually. Air-entrapment is an issue with manual mixing, but this is not the case with the static mixer-based approach.
Fibre spreading station: A unique component of the Clean wet-filament winding technique is the controlled spreading of the fibre bundles prior to impregnation. Fibre spreading effectively increases the width of the tow with a concomitant reduction in the nominal thickness. This enhances the transverse impregnation of the mixed resin system into the fibres. The technology associated with fibre spreading will be presented in a subsequent publication.10
Resin impregnation unit: A schematic illustration of the resin impregnation unit is shown in Figure 3. The final key component of the resin impregnation unit is the roller that ‘collects’ the impregnated tows and enables them to be deposited on the rotating mandrel as a ribbon. This resin applicator serves as a combined pin, miniature bath and injection-based impregnator.
Location of the resin applicator or resin impregnation unit: In the Clean filament winding process, the resin applicator is located on the traverse carriage and the final roller of the resin applicator (see Figure 2) is positioned above the mandrel. Therefore, unlike the conventional wet-filament winding process, here the possibility of the resin dripping from the impregnated tows on to the floor is eliminated.
Feedback control: A feedback control system between the rotating mandrel and the resin dispensing unit is used to control the relative throughput of the resin and hardener.
Figure 3.
Schematic illustration of the clean filament winding process. The key components are coded as follows. (A) Fibre creels. (B) Fibre guide. (C) Tensioning system. (D) Guide pins. (G) Resin-impregnated fibre bundles. (H) Traversing carriage with a platform/adaptor to house the integrated fibre spreading unit and resin impregnator (viii). (I) ‘Collector’ roller or D-Ring. (J) Rotating mandrel. (K) Feedback control unit to synchronise the resin dispensing unit to the fibre haul-off rate or rotation speed of the mandrel. Refer to Figure 2 for a description of (i-viii).

sec.title: Design criteria for the resin impregnation unit
sec.p:
The general design requirements were as follows:
Minimising solvent usage and resin wastage: The design aspects considered here were to minimize the volume of the resin bath or reservoir. The rationale was that a significantly reduced reservoir would require a lower volume of solvent for cleaning at the end of a production run. The reduction in the volume of the resin reservoir would also result in a lower volume of mixed resin that would need to be disposed. In addition, there was a need to minimize the number of contact points between the impregnated fibre tows and the processing equipment. In general, the conventional resin bath is located away from the mandrel and this can result in excess resin on the fibre tows being deposited on the floor. A solution to this problem was to locate the impregnation unit in close proximity or above the mandrel.11
Ease of assembly and disassembly: As the resin impregnation unit was intended for use in an industrial environment, it was necessary to ensure that the fibre bundles or tows could be threaded through the impregnator easily.
Modular assembly: In general, most commercially available resin baths tend to be fixed-volume systems. In other words, the diameter of the resin pick-up drum and the volume of the reservoir tend to be fixed. Therefore, in the current design, a modular design was considered where the volume of the reservoir could be altered depending on the dimensions of the tows and the number of tows used.
Fibre spreading: Previous researchers have demonstrated that the relative dimensions of the fibre bundle can have a significant influence on the impregnation time. Therefore, a dedicated fibre spreading facility was integrated into the design.12–14,15
Impregnation efficiency: A primary prerequisite in the Clean wet-filament winding process was to ensure thorough wetting and impregnation of the fibre tows. The key parameters that influence the impregnation efficiency are as follows: (a) resin viscosity;12,16 (b) porosity of the fibre bundle; (c) resin injection pressure;16 (d) fibre tension;13 and (e) fibre architecture within the fibre bundle.14,17,18
Prior to discussing the design for the resin injection unit, a brief summary of relevant previous publications is presented below.

Most of the resin impregnation models that study the flow of resin through the fibre reinforcements originate from Darcy’s law.13,16 Foley and Gillespie12 expressed Darcy’s law using a cylindrical coordinate system to predict the infiltration time through a circular fibre bundle with and without any entrapped air. In the current work, the equation proposed by Foley and Gillespie12 was adapted to represent a bundle with a rectangular cross section as it mimics the profile of the bundle at the resin impregnation unit. Adapting the equations developed by Foley and Gillespie,12 here the impregnation was assumed to take place over an arbitrary change in the infiltration thickness T1 = s1To to T2 = s2To where s1 and s2 can be varied over the range of 1 (for empty tow) to rf/To (for a fully impregnated fibre-bundle), rf is the radius of the fibre: (1)Δt=η(1-Vf)T02[s12(ln(1s1)2+1)-s22(ln(1s1)2+1)4K(T,H)(Pc+Papp)] where, Δt is the infiltration time, η is the viscosity of the resin system, Vf is the fibre volume fraction, To is the total thickness of the tow and K(T,H) is the transverse permeability. T denotes transverse permeability and H is for ‘hexagonal’ fibre packing in the tow, Pc is the capillary pressure and Papp is the applied pressure. Here, the applied pressure Papp at a specified location along the path of impregnation is taken as the sum of any external pressures that may include: (i) the pressure (Pw) that is generated in the resin layer that is present in-between the fibre bundle and the surface of the injection pin (this is referred to as the wedge of resin in the subsequent text) and (ii) the injection pressure (Pi) of the incoming resin stream at the injection slot which depends on the pumps that deliver the components of the resin systems and the pressure-drop in supply tubes and the static mixer (see Figure 2). Pw can be estimated from the ‘Laplace equation’; this will be discussed in a subsequent section. The resin Pi can be measured experimentally by using a pressure transducer near the injection point.
Equation (1) was used to estimate the impregnation time for a fibre bundle with a rectangular cross-section, assuming that the principle direction of impregnation is through-the-thickness.

The E-glass fibre bundles used in the current study were EC 15 1200 TEX (PPG Industries, UK) with a density of 2550 kg.m−3. The fibre radius (rf) was 8.5 micrometres and the number of filaments (N) in the fibre bundle was approximately 2000. The cross-sectional area of the fibre bundle was defined as: (2)A=NAfVf where Vf is the fibre volume fraction and Af is the cross-sectional area of a single filament.
Assuming the cross section of the spread fibre bundle to be rectangular, the fibre thickness (To) can be estimated using the following relationship: (3)To=AW

The capillary pressure, Pc, can be calculated using the Young-Laplace equation:14 (4)Pc=4ζcosθDE where ζ is the surface tension of the resin, θ is the contact angle between the resin and fibre and DE is the (wetted diameter) for an array of unidirectional fibres:17 (5)DE=8rfFɛ1-ɛ where rf is the fibre radius, ε is the porosity of the fibre bundle and F is a form factor which is a function of the fibre architecture and the direction of resin flow. The form factor ‘F ’ has values of 2 and 4 for transverse and axial flow, respectively.

The Pc in the E-glass fibre bundle was calculated using equation (4) where the fibre volume fraction was assumed to be 0.7 and the contact angle and the surface tension were assumed to be 57° and 0.044 N/m, respectively.17 The Pc was calculated to be 6.58 kPa. The pressure (Pw) was calculated using the Laplace equation:18 (6)Pw=TWR where Pw is the maximum pressure acting on the resin layer that is entrapped between the surface of the resin injection pin and the traversing fibre bundle, T is the tension in the fibre bundle and R is the radius of curvature of the bundle which is assumed to be the same as radius of the pin. The estimated resin pressure was found to be 83.3 kPa, for the case when the fibre width (W), tension in the fibre bundle (T) and radius of curvature (R) were assumed to be 8 mm, 10 N and 15 mm, respectively.

The transverse permeability of the fibre bundle was predicted by using the model proposed by Gebart:16 (7)K(T,H)=16rf29π6(VAVf-1)5/2 where rf is the radius of the fibre, VA is the maximum fibre volume fraction that can be achieved when the fibres are touching. For a hexagonal packing of the fibres in the bundle, VA is given by π23 = 0.907. Using the dimensions of the E-glass bundle presented previously and assuming a fibre volume fraction of 0.7, the transverse permeability from Equation (7) was calculated to be 1.12 × 10−13 m2.

sec.title: Modes of impregnation
sec.p:
A summary of known (or assumed) and calculated values for specified parameters associated with the design of the resin injector is presented in Table 1. With reference to the impregnation unit illustrated in Figure 5, the operation of this system is based on a combination of four impregnation modes. Mode-I represents the case where the fibre tows enter the resin impregnation nozzle, the wedge of resin between the surface of the resin applicator and the fibre bundle is squeezed into the tow (through-the-thickness). Mode-II is where the resin is injected into the fibre bundle at the impregnation nozzle via the Pi. Mode-III represents the situation where the miniature resin trap or reservoir that is positioned below the impregnation nozzle serves as a resin pick-up point and here capillary action is considered to be the contributing factor for impregnation. Finally, Mode-IV represents the case where the scraper-bar that is located downstream of the injection nozzle serves to aid through-thickness impregnation. A schematic illustration of the resin applicator and the four impregnation zones is shown is Figure 5. Table 1.
Summary of known (or assumed) and calculated values for specified parameters associated with the design of the resin injector
Parameter Units Value
Viscosity of the resin (η) Pa·s 0.35
Fiber volume fraction (Vf) % 70
Porosity of the fiber bundle (ε) % 30
Thickness of the tow (τ) µm 80
Width of the tow (W) mm 8
Radius of the fiber (rf) µm 8.5
Linear bundle density (TEX) g/km 1200
Number of fibers in a bundle (N) – ∼2000
Surface tension of the resin (ζ) N/m 0.044
Contact angle between fiber and resin (°) Degrees 57
Form factor for direction of the resin flow in the bundle (dimensionless) – 2
Tension in the fiber bundle (T) N 10
Curvature of the fiber bundle that is in contact with the impregnation pin (R) mm 15
Maximum fiber packing (VA) % 90.7
Fiber architecture – Hexagonal
Calculated values
Area of fiber bundle (A) mm2 0.65
Wetted diameter (DE) mm 0.0145
Transverse capillary pressure (Pc) kPa 6.58
Applied pressure in the resin layer between fibre and impregnation pin (Papp) kPa 83.3
Transverse permeability (KT,H) m2 1.12×10−13
Time taken for impregnation (Δt) s 0.0152

With reference to the process parameters that influence the impregnation process, the following assumptions have been made for the simulations shown in Figures 6–11:
the fibre bundle is stationary and the resin infiltrates the fibre bundle from one side;
each mode of impregnation (see Figure 5) acts independently;
the impregnation occurs across a cross-sectional area of 0.65 mm2 of the bundle as shown in Figure 4 and
only transverse impregnation is considered.
Figure 4.
Schematic illustration of the cross-section of the rectangular spread fibre bundle under the impregnation pin. Here rf is the radius of the fibre, To is the original thickness of the bundle and Ti is the thickness that has been impregnated with the resin. Adapted from Foley and Gillespie.12. Figure 5.
Schematic illustration of the zones within the resin applicator that correspond to the four impregnation modes. Figure 6.
Comparison of impregnation time for the four modes of impregnation considered. Here the pressure in the wedge section at resin injection nozzle (Pw) was assumed to 83.3 kPa, the capillary pressure (Pc) was 6.6 kPa, the pressure at the scraper bar (Psc) was 417 kPa, the resin injection pressure (Pi) was 13.8 kPa, the width of the bundle was taken as 8 mm and the tension in the bundle was 10 N.

A comparison of the four impregnation modes described above is shown in Figure 6. In the following text, the term ‘degree of impregnation’ represents the tow cross-sectional area (0.65 mm2) that has been impregnated completely.

It can be seen in Figure 6 that impregnation is faster via Modes I and IV. This is because a higher driving pressure is developed in the resin film that is present in the wedge section between the bundle and the surface of the pin, thus promoting the squeezing of the resin through the fibre tow. In the pin-based impregnation process, the impregnation takes place over a relatively small portion of the pin as compared to the contact length. This section was named as the ‘impregnation zone’ by Chandler et al.15 In this zone, the thickness of the resin film decreases continuously and reaches a constant value. The minimum value of the resin film was reported to be 50 and 20 µm by Chandler et al.15 and Bates and Charrier,18 respectively. In the contact region between the fibre tow and pin where the resin film thickness reaches a constant value, no ‘further’ impregnation takes place; the resin that is present in the fibre bundle is said to redistribute itself within the tow.13 The simulation for Mode-II impregnation shows that a longer period is required to impregnate the fibre bundle when the resin Pi is set to 13.8 kPa (2 psi). This pressure value was chosen to replicate the situation where the resin was injected using a low-pressure system. The effect of various resin Pis is shown in Figure 7. With reference to Figure 5, the third mode of impregnation is considered to be via Pc where it is seen that when compared to the other modes of impregnation, it is the slowest. The Pc-based impregnation is also important because the residence time for this mode of impregnation can be significantly longer than the other mechanisms discussed previously. Additional impregnation as the impregnated tows are wound on the mandrel is also possible. Figure 7.
Effect of injection pressure on the impregnation time. Here the width of the bundle was taken as 8 mm and the tension in the bundle was 10 N.

sec.title: Effect of Pi
sec.p: The effect of the Pi on the impregnation time is presented in Figure 7. It can be seen from Equation (1) that the time for impregnation is inversely proportional to the applied pressure. As expected, increasing the Pi from 20 kPa to 140 kPa results in a significant reduction in the time to completely impregnate the fibre bundle. Higher injection pressures, in the range of 300 kPa to 1000 kPa, have been reported for closed-mould injection systems.19

Ahmadi et al.20 reported that the impregnation of 2400 Tex glass fibre with molten polypropylene was increased by 10% when pressure was increased from 17.6 kPa to 20.6 kPa. However, the impregnation was reduced by 18% when the pressure was increased from 20.6 kPa to 25.5 kPa. The reported reduction in the impregnation was due to a decrease in the permeability at higher pressures. The simulation shown in Figure 7 assumed that the permeability was independent of Pi.

sec.title: Effect of the thickness of the fibre bundle
sec.p:
The schematic illustration presented in Figure 2 shows the location of the fibre spreading station (item coded (x)) where the fibres are subjected to lateral spreading; the fibres are also subjected to additional spreading at the entry point of the resin impregnation unit (item coded viii). As the thickness of the fibre bundle is reduced, the time for transverse impregnation is lowered as described by Equation (1). A simulation of the effect of increasing the width of the bundle and hence decreasing the thickness of the bundle on the impregnation time is shown in Figure 8. From a practical viewpoint, a balance needs to be achieved between the degree of fibre spreading (to aid impregnation) and fibre damage and segmentation. Fibre damage can cause detrimental effects to the mechanical properties of the composites while excessive segmentation can cause air-entrapment leading to voids in the composites.10 Figure 8.
Effect of the thickness of a fibre bundle on the degree of impregnation. Here the tension in the fibre bundle was fixed at 10 N and the fibre width was changed from 4 mm to 12 mm.

sec.title: Effect of tension
sec.p:
The overall tension in a fibre bundle is generated as a result of the pre-tension, the friction forces in the resin pool and the contact surfaces. The progressive tension build-up for a traversing fibre bundle in contact with a pin can be approximated as a function of the process parameters.15 Tension in the fibre bundle influences the impregnation process in two counter-acting ways: (i) it increases the pressure in the resin film (Pw) according to Equation (6) and (ii) it decreases the permeability (K) of the bundle. As the tension in the tow is increased, the fibres within the bundle are packed more closely, thus causing the permeability of the bundle to decrease.12,14 A number of the impregnation models reported previously have been derived assuming steady-state conditions where the changes in the permeability as a result of varying the processing parameters are not considered. This is because data is required on the changes that are taking place in the fibre volume fraction during the impregnation process. Brenan and Walrath21 reported on a numerical model where the permeability was taken into account as a function of the changes in the packing architecture of the bundle. Their study was performed on a custom-built polycarbonate fibre cradle using water as the wetting liquid in a closed mould system. In the current case, the dynamic changes in the permeability at the micro-scale are not considered. The effect of tension on the fibre bundle on impregnation is shown in Figure 9. Here, it was assumed that transverse permeability was independent of the applied tension. Figure 9.
Effect of fibre tension on the impregnation time and the degree of impregnation. Here the width of the fibre is 8 mm and capillary pressure (Pc) was 6.6 kPa.

sec.title: Effect of viscosity of the resin on impregnation
sec.p:
In accordance with Equation (1), the impregnation time increases with increasing viscosity of the resin. With reference to the resin bath, the viscosity of the resin system can increase with time as discussed previously. This can be exacerbated if there are regions within the resin bath where the resin system can stagnate.19 The influence of the viscosity of the resin system on the impregnation time is shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
Effect of resin viscosity on the time and degree of impregnation. Here the width of the bundle is 8 mm and tension in the bundle is 10 N. Figure 11.
Effect of bundle Tex (linear density) on the impregnation time and degree of impregnation. Here the width of the bundle is 8 mm and tension in the bundle is 10 N.

sec.title: Effect of fibre bundle Tex on impregnation
sec.p: The effect of fibre Tex (linear density of the fibre bundle expressed in g/km) on the degree of impregnation is shown in Figure 11. It can be seen that more time is required to impregnate a fibre tow with higher value of Tex.12

sec.title: Effect of winding speed on the degree of impregnation
sec.p:
A schematic illustration of the resin applicator along with the contact lengths available at each of the impregnation zones are presented in Figure 5. A summary of the contact lengths and the associated modes of impregnation are summarised in Table 2. The residence time for the fibre bundle within each of the impregnation zones was obtained by relating the contact length available for each mode of impregnation to the winding speed or the fibre bundle haul-off rate. Table 2.
Summary of the contact length available for the resin applicator as illustrated in Figure 5
Impregnation mode Contact length (mm)
Mode-I (Resin wedge) 15
Mode-II (Resin injection) 2
Mode-III (Resin pool) 35
Mode-IV (Scraper bar) 3

With reference to Figure 12, the impregnation process has been divided into four impregnation zones corresponding to the slopes of the impregnation curves. The first two assumptions stated in the Section Modes of impregnation are not applicable here.
The first zone corresponds to the region where the fibre bundle enters the miniature resin reservoir; here the impregnation takes place via capillary action. Although the rate of impregnation via Mode-III is relatively slow, the impregnation takes place over a longer length.
The second zone, where an increase in the impregnation rate is observed, corresponds to the simultaneous impregnation via the pressure generated in the wedge section of the injection nozzle (Pw), Pc and resin Pi.
The third zone corresponds to the region where the fibre bundle leaves the injection nozzle and reaches the scraper bar. Here the mode of impregnation is predominantly via capillary action.
Finally, the fibre bundle experiences impregnation via the wedge-action at the scraper bar (Mode IV).
Figure 12.
Effect of the winding speed on the degree of impregnation. Here the pressure in the wedge section of the resin injection nozzle (Pw) was 166.6 kPa, the capillary pressure (Pc) was 6.6 kPa, the pressure at the scraper bar (Psc) was 833 kPa, the resin injection pressure (Pi) was 13.8 kPa, the width of the bundle was taken as 8 mm and the tension in the bundle was 20 N.

It can be seen from the Figure 12 that the lower winding speeds favour the degree of impregnation of the fibre bundle. This is because of the increased residence time available for the fibre bundle travelling at lower speeds.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A general discussion on the issues associated with conventional wet-filament winding was presented. These issues ranged from the need for copious volumes of solvent that is required to clean the processing equipment at the end of a production shift. Moreover, fast-curable resin systems cannot be used with conventional wet-filament winding because of the possibility of the resin system curing in the processing equipment. A modified wet-filament winding process was presented where resin and hardener are stored in separate compartments and are pumped on demand to a static mixer where they are mixed intimately. The mixed resin system is then delivered to a custom-designed impregnation unit where the fibre tows are impregnated. The merits of the modified wet-filament winding process (clean filament winding) were discussed. The theoretical basis for the resin impregnation unit was presented where previously reported models were used to simulate the parameters that influence the impregnation efficiency.
Part 2 of this paper will present results where the clean filament winding technique was implemented in the laboratory and on site in industry.

sec.p: The authors wish to acknowledge financial support from the EPSRC (TS/G000387/1) and the Technology Strategy Board projects AB134K, AB135A and BD072K. The support given by the industrial partners (Pultrex, PPG, CTM, Mould Life, Luxfer Gas Cylinders, Halyard and Bruker Optics) is duly acknowledged. GFF acknowledges the financial support provided by the Royal Society.

ack.p: The authors wish to acknowledge the technical assistance provided by Professor Brian Ralph, Seb Ballard and Frank Biddlestone.

sec.title: Conflict of Interest
sec.p: None declared
